title: Homily | Venerable Aloysius Schwartz Mass | Cardinal Donald Wuerl

json.text:
It's truly a great pleasure for me to
join all of you here at St. Andrew the

Apostle Church, as we come together this
evening, not only to celebrate the

Eucharist and reflect on the
significance of the readings that we

just listened to that call us to be
merciful just as God is merciful to us,

but also to reflect on the life of one
of our own Archdiocesan priests, Aloysius

Schwartz, who two years ago was
declared "Venerable" by Pope Francis. The

connection between the Gospel's call
today,

Jesus's request of us, challenge to us, to
to live God's mercy, our obligation to be
witnesses to the many, many ways in which mercy can be extended, and the

extraordinary life of Monsignor Schwartz
will all come together when we

recognize that to truly be a witness to
Jesus Christ, to be his disciple, to be

his follower, we have to bear testimony
to his mercy,

and we have to do that not just with
words, we have to do it with our actions,

the way we live. When God's love,
that created everything that is, when

God's love encountered the mess that we
have made of all of his goodness to us,

his love becomes his mercy, and in the
Gospel, we were challenged to do the same:

to confront one another, to face one
another, and to recognize that we need to

love one another, and that that love of
ours, when it encounters the human

condition of all the ordinary realities
of life, it becomes our compassion, our

mercy. Today, we celebrate one of
the great manifestations of God's love,

God's mercy and God's presence in His
disciples - in a specific disciple, in a

truly missionary disciple. We recognize
this in Monsignor, now Venerable,

Aloysius Schwartz. As I mentioned, two
years ago Pope Francis signed the decree

that Monsignor Schwartz, a native son of
our archdiocese who became a missionary

priest, has lived a life of heroic virtue.
That's what the decree, that's what

becoming recognized as Venerable is all
about: the first step, recognizing a life

of heroic virtue, and now, now we refer to
him as Venerable, because that

recognition is so evident; the first
priest in the history of our archdiocese

to be so designated, to be so singled out
by the Church for his goodness, but more

than just his goodness, for a form of
service that was truly heroic. The

priest's cause for canonization has has
been promoted now by the Archdiocese of

Manila in the Philippines because that's
where he carried out his

work for so long, and that's where he
died and is buried.

We are particularly pleased to have with
us today, as a concelebrant of this Mass,

Father Samson, postulator of the cause.
He is here so that he can join us in

this celebration, lifting up an
extraordinary priest.
You might ask what a postulator does. The postulator is the person responsible for

collecting and preparing all of the
material available to be able to support

the claim that Monsignor Schwartz is
truly worthy of the recognition we

attribute to him of his sanctity. The
proctor, the postulator,

has to then receive and present to Rome
all the evidences of the sanctity of our

beloved priest, and also any claims for
a miracle, because that's the next step

in moving this cause along its way.
Venerable Aloysius Schwartz was born in

September 1930 of a wonderful Catholic
family. He attended Holy Name Church, he

was baptized there, received his first
communion, was confirmed and graduated

from the parish school, so we have great
claims to him even though Manila now

has the cause of the eventual
beatification and canonization. His

desire as a youngster, even as a
youngster, he recognized he wanted to be

a missionary, and he said this, and 
proclaimed it often.

That heartfelt desire was confirmed
years later when, as a seminarian, he

visited the shrine of the Virgin of the
Poor in Belgium, and he was so inspired

by that visit and the recognition of
Mary's special rule in relation to the

poor, that he dedicated his priesthood to
the Virgin of the Poor and to serving

the poor with Mary's love. And following
his ordination to the priesthood in 1957
at St. Martin of Tours Church in Washington, he went, he was assigned in response to

his request, to South Korea, where at that
time, you might remember, we're following

the Korean War, and there was great
devastation and enormous poverty, and

many of the people that Venerable
Aloysius served lived in extremely poor

conditions, and he chose to live with
them. He said, "One's surroundings definitely
condition one's thinking," and then he went on to explain, "by living more or less poor, I

discover it was easier to think poor,
to feel poor and to say that I am

one of those I am trying to serve." It was
something similar to what Pope Francis
speaks about, although Monsignor Aloysius had encountered it long before, that the

shepherd should have the feel and sense
and even the smell of the flock. He lived that.
It was with Gospel zeal that Father Al, as

he was affectionately known, then founded
the sisters of Mary and established

programs that would provide care,
education, hope for a brighter future for

the young people that they cared for, and
later he founded the Brothers of

Christ, also for the same mission, and
we're very honored to have with us today

at this Mass some of the Sisters of Mary,
including their Superior, and it's just

so good to have you here as a visible
sign of the continuing work of Venerable, although all

the Sisters that he had founded, formed,
called "Father Al." Venerable Aloysius'
legacy lives on. It lives on in the boystown and girlstown programs that the

Sisters of Mary operate in South Korea,
the Philippines, Mexico, Brazil, Guatemala

and Honduras. Mexico and Honduras are
represented here in the sanctuary by the
choir, and in those institutions
more than 20,000 youngsters are educated. The Sisters' motto remains, "let us serve

the Lord with joy," and that joy pervades,
permeates, is just a part of all of their

mission and ministry. Present today here
to my right are 30 young girls from the

choir of the girlstown school in
Chalco, Mexico, and also from Honduras,

and also up to a hundred graduates all
here from the many institutions that

trace their origins all the way back to
Father Al. And present today with us are

some who have been so inspired by the
life of Father Al that they continue

not only to support his work in various
parts of the world, but to help spread

the message of this holy example
this wonderful work that is, he is,

carried on today in the Sisters of Mary
With us today are Tom and Gauri Sullivan,
who not only knew and worked with Father, but who continued to be so involved in

that legacy that we were just very, very
grateful, and are grateful for the
opportunity to say so. In his book, "To Live Is Christ," this was a
book that Father, then Monsignor and now Venerable, Schwartz, wrote on spirituality

for the Sisters of Mary. He tells us,
"Christ not only gives the poor

priority, he identifies with the poor. He
becomes one of them."
"Henceforth," he went on to say, "whatever you do for the poor, you do for Christ," and

isn't that what Jesus himself told us?
When you see someone in need, you see

Christ. When you give food to the hungry,
or drink to the thirsty or welcome the

stranger, you're caring for Christ. Pope
Francis tells us that the Good Shepherd

has to walk with the flock. Only, only
with the eyes of faith, however, can we

see as Pope Francis tells us, "when you
walk with the flock, you have to carry

the cross and help them carry theirs."
But only with the eyes of faith can we

see in the cross so much more, so much
more than just the suffering that one endures. What

makes it possible for us to see beyond
the ruined body of Jesus of Nazareth on

the cross is our faith, and it was the
faith in Jesus that motivated Father Al,

motivates the Sisters of Mary, motivates
that whole effort around the world to

continue that work. It's our faith that
helps us understand and embrace Jesus's
command: "you must be My witnesses. How else will
people come to know of My love? How else will they come to know of all the good

they're supposed to do if they don't see
it in others,

if you don't bear witness?" Venerable
Father Schwartz bore his cross: terminal

amyotrophic lateral sclerosis - Lou
Gehrig's disease. But he bore it with

joy, with faith, with perseverance, even,
and we see the pictures of him in his

very real physical struggles being
present - overseeing some of the works,

planning a school for girls from a
wheelchair - because it was the only way

he could be present. A number of years
ago, the inspiring story of Monsignor

Schwartz's life he told in an
autobiographical book called "Killing me

Softly." As the disease simply took his
strength, his energy, his life, but

never his faith, and never his love
for the Lord

and his love for the Lord's poor, and that
includes all of us. He carried out the

work that he said he wanted to do from
the day he was ordained: stand with those

in need, preach the Lord and His love
to them and tried to be a sign of it. We

reflect on the Gospel call today to
share, to share gratitude for the mercy

we've received, to be able, to be able to
be merciful ourselves, and so we thank

God. We thank God for the example of
Venerable Monsignor Aloysius Swartz, an
example this world so much needs, because we're so caught up in so many other

realities that we may not all receive
the opportunity to be there for another,

to see the opportunity to care for
another. God, God, has given us this

extraordinary priest so that we might be
inspired by his holy life, instructed by

his example and encouraged by his
preaching.

We thank God for our own hometown
Servant of God,
the Venerable Aloysius Schwartz. We thank God that here, in our part of the world, the

faith has nurtured a person, a priest, a
model of Christ's care for others, to the

point where he's now recognized for his
heroic virtue, a Servant of God, and may we,

may we, simply see in him inspiration for
our commitment to the Gospel, to

compassion, to mercy, and above all else,
as the Gospel tells us today, to the

forgiveness that is ours in Christ that
we need to share with everyone else.
